Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: The school reports that the child was caught bullying a classmate, and the father needs to respond
Expectation2: Provide initial medical care to patients
Situation2: The ambulance driver is conducting a routine check of the first-aid kit to ensure all supplies are present and not expired.
Story: I was halfway through checking the ambulance’s first-aid kit, making sure every bandage and vial was accounted for, when my phone buzzed. It was the school. My heart sank as the principal’s voice told me my son had been caught bullying another child. They needed me to come in and discuss it immediately. As a father, I knew I had to be there for my son, to understand what happened and help him learn from his mistake. But as an ambulance driver, I couldn’t just leave the kit unchecked—lives depended on it being ready. My supervisor expected me to finish the inspection before my shift started, and any missing supplies could mean disaster for a patient. I felt torn, the weight of both roles pressing down on me. My son needed his father, but my community needed me to be prepared. I stared at the half-checked kit, my phone still in my hand, caught between two worlds that both demanded all of me.
